text: The extraordinary Hastert hearing: a sentencing for an obscure financial crime turns into a forum on sexual abuse. http://nyti.ms/26tR08q
author: juliebosman

text: Court is adjourned. Jolene Burdge, sister of abuse victim, hugs family and supporters. Hastert remains seated in courtroom.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge's final words before exiting: "This is a horrible case.. horrible for our country. I hope I never have to see a case like this again."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, on Hastert: "I will allow him to self-surrender."
author: juliebosman

text: Dennis Hastert, former Speaker of the House, is sitting motionless as he is sentenced to 15 months in federal prison.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge: I am also sentencing Hastert to two years of supervised release.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge: I am sentencing the defendant to 15 months incarceration.
author: juliebosman

text: Here we go. Judge: "The defense wants me to impose a sentence of probation. Any sentence of straight probation would be inappropriate."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge: I spoke to the warden of a BoP facility, who assured me that "the defendant's health needs will be met if he is incarcerated."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, who has not yet said whether Hastert will serve prison time, says that BoP is well equipped to care for inmates with health issues.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge reminds courtroom again of extraordinary fact: Hastert called Tom Cross, brother of one of his abuse victims, asking for his support.
author: juliebosman

text: Yes, Hastert is 74, says the judge. But "he’s not an infirm, helpless, handicapped senior citizen who is unaware of what’s going on."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, on Hastert: "If there’s a public shaming of the defendant because of the conduct he’s engaged in, so be it."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, praising Scott Cross for testifying on Hastert's sexual abuse: "I believe everything Mr. Cross said."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge to Hastert: Any sentence I give you today would "pale" to what you would have received in state court for committing sexual abuse.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge tells Hastert that he is especially aggravated that someone with Hastert's education and background would commit these crimes.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge begins to describe in graphic detail when Hastert molested Victim A, 14-year-old, while on a wrestling trip in Colorado.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge talks about how the 1970's were different from today. Back then, he said, can you imagine accusing "the town hero of molesting you?"
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, on Hastert: "Some actions can obliterate a lifetime of good works," calling him a "serial child molester" for the third time.
author: juliebosman

text: Sidenote: Hastert's lawyer has removed his glasses, keeps covering his eyes with his hand, and is staring downward. Does not look pleased.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge blasts Hastert for trying to "set up" Individual A, actions that were "intentional, thought out, and desperate."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, to Hastert: "You manipulated the FBI and the U.S. attorney’s office. And that’s a big problem for you."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge says that typically, structuring violations result in little to no prison time. "This case is different from those cases," he said.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge says Hastert's lying to the FBI was "deplorable," especially "by a person who knew better."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge recounting Hastert's actions in a brusque tone. Repeatedly calls him a liar and child molester. "You lied, and here we are."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, on Hastert: "What rational person takes out $1.7 million in cash from a bank" over several years?
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, in a sharp tone: Hastert's cash withdrawals were a crime, his explanations to the FBI for his actions were "preposterous."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge, on Hastert: "The defendant is a serial child molester."
author: juliebosman

text: Judge Durkin is moments away from naming Hastert sentence. Says he has discretion to vary above or below the federal guidelines.
author: juliebosman

text: The judge asks Hastert if he sexually abused Mr. Cross, who testified today. Hastert: "I don’t remember that, but I accept his statement."
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert apologizes to the victims; his family; to the court; to the people of the United States.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert:"I am sorry to those I have hurt and misled. What I did was wrong and I regret it. They looked to me and I took advantage of them."
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert: "For 11 months, I have been struggling to come to terms with events that occurred almost 40 years ago."
author: juliebosman

text: "I am deeply ashamed to be standing before you today," Hastert says. "I mistreated some of athletes that I coached."
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert unsteadily rises from his wheelchair, preparing to speak. He is using his walker to approach the lectern.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert atty asks for probation and, if necessary, home confinement.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert atty wraps up, talking of question of punishment: "In both my heart and my mind I do not believe that more is necessary."
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert atty: "I have genuine compassion for all the victims. But I also have a great deal of compassion for Mr. Hastert."
author: juliebosman

text: Throughout 45-minute hearing so far, Hastert has remained seated, hands clasped together, staring at the ground. He has spoken three words.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert atty: Hastert's sons "have come here this morning to demonstrate their support for their father." No mention of his wife, Jean.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert defense atty continues to plead that judge consider the "arc" of Hastert's life.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert lawyer: After Hastert was confronted by sex abuse victim years ago & asked for money, Hastert was flooded by anxiety, panic, fear.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert lawyer, to judge: After "misconduct that occurred many years ago," he "reshaped his life into a career of public service."
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert prosecutor argues to judge that Hastert should be "held accountable for all of the crimes he committed."
author: juliebosman

text: Scott Cross, after emotional testimony of the lifelong trauma he experienced from Hastert sexual abuse, has left the courtroom.
author: juliebosman

text: "I’ve always felt that what Coach Hastert had done to me was my darkest secret," says alleged sex abuse victim in open court.
author: juliebosman

text: Scott Cross, describing sexual abuse by Hastert, is standing at lectern, audibly crying. Hastert is several feet away in his wheelchair.
author: juliebosman

text: "Coach Hastert sexually abused me my senior year of high school," says alleged Hastert victim, as he begins to weep.
author: juliebosman

text: Individual D takes the stand: identifies himself as Scott Cross, 53, Chicago area resident. Tells courtroom that he was a H.S. wrestler.
author: juliebosman

text: "You took his life, Mr. Hastert," says sister of alleged Hastert sex abuse victim. Hastert stares in direction of judge.
author: juliebosman

text:
"Don’t be a coward, Mr. Hastert," Ms. Burdge says. "Tell the truth.
What you did wasn’t misconduct. It was sexual abuse of a minor."
author: juliebosman

text: "I hope I have been your worst nightmare," Ms. Burdge tells Hastert in open court, her voice cracking.
author: juliebosman

text: Reinboldt died of AIDS in 1995; he told his sister that he had been abused by Hastert in high school.
author: juliebosman

text: Jolene Burdge, sister of alleged Hastert sex abuse victim, begins her testimony. She reads a letter from her brother, Stephen Reinboldt.
author: juliebosman

text: Prosecution says they will call as witnesses Jolene Burdge and Individual D, one of Hastert's alleged victims. No witnesses from defense.
author: juliebosman

text: Judge Durkin asks if Hastert has read presentence report: "Yes, I have," he answered.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert briefly rose from his wheelchair as Judge Durkin entered the courtroom.
author: juliebosman

text: Hastert, wearing a dark suit and glasses, is sitting across a table from his lawyer, Thomas Green, waiting for the judge to enter courtroom.
author: juliebosman

text: Dennis Hastert just entered the courtroom in a wheelchair, an aide carrying a walker. He is sitting with his hand resting on his chin.
author: juliebosman

text: 30 minutes before Hastert hearing begins, the former Speaker is out of sight. He faces up to 5 yrs in prison; possibly just probation.
author: juliebosman

text: "When are we going to get rid of Ferguson mayor, city council and chief?" a speaker begins. "I'm tired of police brutality."

author: juliebosman

text: The police are putting on their gas masks.
author: juliebosman

text: Police shout "Gas! Gas! Gas!"
author: juliebosman

text: And the police are heading down Florissant toward protesters. Standoff.
author: juliebosman

text: Too many cops to count. One just ordered "Prepare to move forward!"
author: juliebosman

text: "You must disperse immediately," officer announces.
author: juliebosman

author: juliebosman

text: These vehicles just pulled up #Ferguson

text: Crowd begins moving up West Florissant, chanting. "No justice, no curfew." Police seem ready. #Ferguson
author: juliebosman

text: Journalists get back to a penned-off staging area at midnight, before we turn into pumpkins at curfew. #Ferguson
author: juliebosman

text: Five minutes till curfew, lots of police in place. #Ferguson
author: juliebosman

text: Several dozen protesters, many intoxicated, remain in the parking lot of Red's BBQ, at the corner of W. Florissant and Canfield. #Ferguson

author: juliebosman

author: juliebosman

text: Ron Johnson: "The frustration that is in your home is in my home." #Ferguson

text: Nixon: "We can't have looting and crimes at night. We can't have people fearful." #Ferguson

text: I'd say this is less of a "press conference" than a "town hall where people can shout at the governor." #Ferguson

text: Awaiting details on curfew: which area will be affected? Will violators be arrested? #Ferguson
author: juliebosman

text: Capt. Ron Johnson of highway patrol: "We will survive this. We will make a change."

text: Curfew begins at midnight and ends at 5 a.m.

text: Nixon: "In the morning, this community will rise with the sun to renew its quest for justice."

text: Loss for the prosecution: Wafer's front porch is now considered part of his home. How will this affect castle doctrine, duty to retreat?
author: juliebosman

text: Interesting: judge will give jury an instruction that a front porch is part of the home. Does that mean Renisha McBride was in Wafer's home?
author: juliebosman

text: Question before the judge now: is there evidence that Renisha McBride was attempting to break into Wafer's home?
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer's testimony is complete.
author: juliebosman

text: The prosecutor picked up a shotgun and waved it near jury box, causing gasps from jurors.
author: juliebosman

text: Less than two weeks later, Renisha McBride showed up on his front porch; Wafer says he didn't remember the gun was loaded.
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer says that after his car was paintballed, he "got a little paranoid" and loaded his shotgun for the first time.
author: juliebosman

text: Prosecutor suggests that Wafer, an occasional hunter, concealed his knowledge of guns to police to make shooting appear accidental.
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer, on the shooting: "It was just a self-defense reaction to protect myself." Prosecutor: "You’ve got a lot of buzzwords, Mr. Wafer."
author: juliebosman

text: Question in Wafer trial at the moment: was McBride "knocking" or "banging" on his doors? Wafer has described it both ways.
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer: "This was violent banging. This was unbelievable. I still can’t wrap my mind around it that a woman could make these sounds."
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer told police that when he confronted Renisha McBride w/a gun, "I'm not sure what I said, you know, because I'm piss and vinegar now."
author: juliebosman

text: As Wafer testified that he "didn't stare at the body" of Renisha McBride, several of her relatives covered their mouths and wept.
author: juliebosman

text: Why didn't Wafer tell police that he was scared? "I didn’t want to come across as less of a man," he said.
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer: "I had a lot of emotions. I was scared, I had fear, I was panicking."
author: juliebosman

text: Prosecutor, to Wafer: "You didn’t call the police because you were mad and you wanted to handle this thing yourself, right?"
author: juliebosman

text: Wafer returns to the stand to be cross-examined, answering questions in a soft voice.
